title: Datasheets are your friends!
content:
A close cousin of the datasheet is the humble user manual. 

Datasheets provide all details about the component/system you are using. The datasheet is generally written by the manufacturer of the component. For common/unbranded components such as LEDs, resistors etc. it is suggested that you collect the most important parameters(Power rating, supply voltage, operating temperature etc.) during purchasing. 

For most ICs/transistors, a datasheet is a god send. It eliminates ambiguity from your design and allows you to design proper circuit topology, identify errors in your circuit etc.

So how do you interpret a datasheet?

Datasheets for each component are read differently. There is no set format or guideline that every datasheet follows. However, a good datasheet always contains the following:

1. Description of the component

2. Maximum and minimum parameters

3. Physical dimensions

4. Pinout diagrams+pin function descriptions

If you have any questions regarding datasheets, ask one of your co-ordinators. 
User manuals for all the equipment available in MARVEL are stored in the lab. Ask the co-ordinator on duty if you want to use any of the documents.

Datasheets are freely available online. If the datasheet for a particular component has not been listed below, find it on the internet.

# List of datasheets:
### 1. [555](https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/lm555.pdf)
### 2.[ IC 7447](https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/sn5447a.pdf?ts=1633177112671&ref_url=https%253A%252F%252Fwww.google.com%252F)
### 3. [BC 547](https://www.sparkfun.com/datasheets/Components/BC546.pdf)

title: Friendly Neighborhood Youtubers
content:
Here are some youtube channels that can help you learn/improve your skill and knowledge.
Very often people ask me which YouTube channels I follow to help out with projects, here are a few of them in no particular order. Missed someone you think is a must-add to this list? Do reach out!

[Adam Savage](https://www.youtube.com/c/tested): Adam Savage from Mythbusters needs no introduction I presume.

[Ben Eater](https://www.youtube.com/c/BenEater): For all you electronic hardware enthusiasts

[Jeremy Fielding](https://www.youtube.com/c/JeremyFieldingSr/videos): For all you mechanical/ CAD designers.

[EEV Blog](https://www.youtube.com/c/EevblogDave): Another Electronics Channel for cool projects.

[Makers Muse](https://www.youtube.com/c/MakersMuse): All about the 3D printing world.

[James Bruton](https://www.youtube.com/c/jamesbruton): Another maker who uses 3D prints to bring complex mechanisms to life.

[CNC kitchen](https://www.youtube.com/c/CNCKitchen): Taking 3D printing technology testing to the next level.

[Integza](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2avWDLN1EI3r1RZ_dlSxCw): Rockets, Rockets, and more Rockets! Along with some cool 3D printer mechanisms.

[Electroboom](https://www.youtube.com/c/Electroboom): Needs no introduction.

[Great Scott](https://www.youtube.com/c/greatscottlab): Another amazing electronic hardware engineer.

[Simone Giertz](https://www.youtube.com/c/simonegiertz): A youtube creator who builds many cool things.

[Andreas Spiess](https://www.youtube.com/c/AndreasSpiess): Go to YouTuber for communication-based electronics projects.

[Spark Plug](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCSUDSCwC7AUB0wOJXVsKRXg): A lot of everyday models to practice from.

[Fusion360 Beginner playlist 1](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLrOFa8sDv6jfKx9poMArMUV2MGbZoXrCT): A tutorial to cover basics in Fusion 360.

[Fusion360 Beginner playlist 2](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLrZ2zKOtC_-DR2ZkMaK3YthYLErPxCnT-): A 30 day beginner course on fusion 360.

title: Courses for further exploration!
content:
[3D CAD Fundamental](https://www.coursera.org/learn/3d-cad-fundamental): The goal of this course is to construct a three-dimensional model, with the computer as the main teaching material, to enrich the fun paradigm and the complete drawing process.

[Product Development using AutoCad](https://www.coursera.org/projects/product-development-using-autocad): By the end of this 1-hour long project-based course, you will be able to design and draw 2D products customized to fit your needs using AutoCAD Design.

[Introduction to Mechanical Engineering Design and Manufacturing](https://www.coursera.org/learn/mechanical-engineering-design-manufacturing): This course explores the design for manufacturing workflow and shows how to validate models and create the G code, the programming language needed to instruct the CNC machine on how to move. 

[Intro to Digital Manufacturing with Autodesk Fusion 360](https://www.coursera.org/learn/introduction-digital-manufacturing-fusion-360): This course introduces innovations in CAD and digital manufacturing, speaking to the rapid changes taking place that are forever transforming the future of making.

[3D Printing Software](https://www.coursera.org/learn/3d-printing-software): This course is hands-on in nature and will provide step-by-step instructions to guide you through two popular 3D modeling programs, Tinkercad and Fusion 360. 

[Autodesk Fusion 360 Integrated CAD/CAM/CAE](https://www.coursera.org/learn/fusion-360-integrated-cad-cam-cae): In this course, we take the next step in connecting CAD, CAM, and CAE through a series of short exercises on 3D modeling, rendering, simulation, and computer aided manufacturing.

[Introduction to Programming with MATLAB](https://www.coursera.org/learn/matlab): This course teaches computer programming to those with little to no previous experience. It uses the programming system and language called MATLAB to do so because it is easy to learn, versatile and very useful for engineers and other professionals.

[Introduction to Engineering Mechanics](https://www.coursera.org/learn/engineering-mechanics-statics): This course is an introduction to learning and applying the principles required to solve engineering mechanics problems.

[MATLAB and Octave for Beginners](https://www.edx.org/course/matlab-and-octave-for-beginners): Learn MATLAB and Octave and start experimenting with matrix manipulations data visualizations, functions and mathematical computations.

[Introduction to Engineering and Design](https://www.edx.org/course/introduction-to-engineering-and-design): Learn about the primary fields of engineering and explore the engineering design process, from conceptual design and optimal choice evaluation to prototyping and project construction.

title: Software Downloads
content:
The tasks you perform will require you to download, install and use certain software. Here are a list of useful links for the same

KiCAD:  KiCAD is an open-source tool for electronic design and automation. It facilitates the design of electronic schematics, PCB design, etc. This document has relevant information on the download of KiCAD: https://docs.kicad.org/5.1/en/getting_started_in_kicad/getting_started_in_kicad.html

Fusion 360: Integrated CAD, CAM, CAE, and PCB software.
https://www.autodesk.com/products/fusion-360/overview
If you want a hobbyist license, check out the below link: https://www.autodesk.in/products/fusion-360/personal 

For Slicing your 3D models, install Ultima Cura: https://ultimaker.com/software/ultimaker-cura

title: Jupyter Lab
content:
#### Installation

_Links : [jupyterlab.readthedocs.io](https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/stable/getting_started/installation.html#dockerhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_omZFAgT0TQ)_

- Before Installing JupyterLab, Python needs to be installed in your system.
- Python download [links](https://www.python.org/downloads/windows/)

"IMPORTANT - DONOT INTALL PYTHON 3.10.x - few necessary modules such as sklearn aren't updated to be compatible with it."
"INTALL PYTHON 3.9.x (where x is the latest revision)""

##### TIP
→ Check “Add Python x.x to PATH” 
![](https://miro.medium.com/max/1344/0*7nOyowsPsGI19pZT.png)
This makes sure that you can access python from the any folder in your computer

#### Running JupyterLab for the first time
JupyterLab runs as an application on Jupyter Server hence it needs to run from the command prompt 

```
jupyter lab
```

This single command initializes everything required and opens JupyterLab in your default browser.
JupyterLab can be opened from http://localhost:8888/lab in case it doesn't open automatically

##### TIP

Since JupyterLab runs on Jupyter server, you wont be able to access all the files on your PC directly.

The directory from where the JupyterLab is run from the terminal, is mounted as the root directory.

Whenever you want to work on a project, create a new directory (i.e folder) for it and cd into it. Run `jupyter lab` from there to isolate all your projects

#### Saving your progress

Make a note of the previous TIP, keep your projects isolated and organized neatly.

Saving of a single file can be achieved with Ctrl+S or File>Save

Saving of your complete project can be done by File>Save All

title: Some etiquette
content:
**MARVEL** is a community driven lab. We rely on student volunteers to help organize and maintain lab resources. As a lot of students will use the computer systems in MARVEL, the following set of guidelines (specific to IoT) should be kept in mind before starting any project.

1. You will be working extensively with the arduino IDE and other such software. Certain projects might require installation of additional software/extensions. In such a case always check if the required installation has been done. If not, you can perform the installation after letting the coordinator know.

2. Make sure that you DO NOT change the default installation directory for any new software installations.

3. Try to work on all of your projects on a single system. Create a directory with your name in the system of your choice. All future programs and configurations you make must be stored within that directory.

4. DO NOT delete/edit/modify other students’ directories.

5. DO NOT set passwords to your directory

6. In case, for a particular project, extensive codebases and a complex filestructure is required, it is suggested that you make use of a virtual environment within your system. Contact the coordinators of the relevant domain for more information.

7. In case you use a microcontroller, always flash the program before connecting peripheral components.

8. If you damage any component, let the coordinator on duty know.

title: IoT  hardware essentials
content:
The Raspberry Pi and ESP32 are an essential part of your IoT toolkit. You will utilise these devices to process data from sensors, relay information to the cloud and  trigger required responses in actuators.

So what is a Raspberry Pi?
The Raspberry Pi is a low cost, credit-card sized computer that plugs into a computer monitor or TV, and uses a standard keyboard and mouse(all available in the lab). It is a capable little device that enables people of all ages to explore computing, and to learn how to program in languages like Scratch and Python. It’s capable of doing everything you’d expect a desktop computer to do, from browsing the internet and playing high-definition video, to making spreadsheets, word-processing, and playing games.
You can find out more about the Raspberry Pi by clicking [here](https://www.raspberrypi.com/documentation/)
Get  started with the raspberry pi by clicking [here](https://www.raspberrypi.org/help/what-%20is-a-raspberry-pi/)

What is the ESP32?
ESP32 is a series of low-cost, low-power system on a chip microcontrollers with integrated Wi-Fi and dual-mode Bluetooth. 
Youcan find out more by clicking [here](https://dronebotworkshop.com/esp32-intro/)

title: 3D Printing
content:
#3D Printing
###Abstract
Amongst manufacturing, 3D printing is a very novel way of making things. It is also known as additive manufacturing. A 3D printer is used to 3D print objects. It builds the object layer by layer. There are metal 3D printers and polymer 3D printers. Both of them work very differently but fundamentally, the object is prepared by building layer upon layer.

 Less wastage and ability to manufacture sophisticated objects are the perks of 3D printing. The cost of capital machinery for manufacturing a product is way less in 3D printing as it relies on the principle of additive manufacturing.

The main parts of a 3D printer are as follows. 

- Filament
- Extruder
- Hot End
- Print bed

![Parts of a 3D Printer](http://my3dconcepts.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Hardware-components-of-FDM-3D-Printers.jpg)

###How does it work ?

CAD software is used for designing an object. After it has been designed according to the required specifications, we must convert it to .stl file which shall be interpreted to g-code. G-code guides the 3D Printer for additive manufacturing of the object. 

For any printer to work, it requires a source file which shall be processed to make the product. Object file is created by rapid prototyping using CAD software. Object file is converted to .stl file ( Stereolithograph file ).

![](https://fabheads.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/slicer13-1.png)

 ".stl file" is the source file for 3D printing. Stereolithograph file sliced to computer numerical code called g-code. G-code instructs the 3D printer to manufacture the object.

*G-code is a widely used computer numerical code - CNC programming language. It is used in CAM ( Computer Aided Manufacturing ).*

Cartesian coordinate configured robotic arm shall hold the extruder element. The extruder has a heating element, which shall melt the polymer filament(Eg., PLA filament) and layer by layer, the object is manufactured. 

###3D Printing softwares and open resources
 Ultimaker Cura is a prominently used 3D printing software. It is a open source slicing engine for converting the .stl file to CNC. Using this software, we can begin our journey with 3D Printing.

Ultimaker Cura Download Link : [https://ultimaker.com/software/ultimaker-cura](https://ultimaker.com/software/ultimaker-cura)

[Thingiverse](https://www.thingiverse.com/) is an open-source website where we can find and collaborate our ideas with the 3D printing community. Here, one can download the .obj files of myriad available objects from the website. 

 ### Ultimaker Cura for Splicing and 3D Printing
In order for anything to be printed, the scale, dimensions, material, infill(density and pattern), and support structures are a few important things to remember.

#### Infill Patterns
![infillpattern](https://the3dbros.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Cura-Infill-Patterns.jpg)

#### Support Structures
They are required for building layers of filament while printing in overhanging regions. Support structures are printed along with the object. They are relatively soft and can be broken off later to get the finished object.

![Red-Object
Blue-Support](https://support.ultimaker.com/hc/article_attachments/4405598827922/UseTowers.png)

###Resource Links :

- [3D Printing](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/3d-printing)
- [CNC](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/computer-numerical-control)
- [CAM](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/computer-aided-manufacturing)
- [Rapid Prototyping](https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/rapid-prototyping#:~:text=Rapid%20prototyping%20(RP)
- [Study Materials from Ultimaker Cura](https://ultimaker.com/learn)
